caseTitle: COMM P V KWAKU KLU AND OTHERS
summary: This 1938 West Africa Court of Appeal decision in Accra involved fifty-eight individuals charged with unlawful assembly under section 346 of Cap. 29 for actions on October 24, 1937, at Krachikrom. The Magistrate convicted fifty-four, while four were later acquitted. Although the charge was unlawful assembly, the Magistrate's judgment recorded a conviction for riot, an uncharged offense. The Supreme Court dismissed appeals by all fifty-eight. On further appeal, the West Africa Court of Appeal struck out the appeals of the four unconvicted individuals and corrected the legal error in the convictions of the remaining fifty-four by altering the finding to 'guilty of the offence charged' under sections 319 and 326 of Cap. 10, while upholding the original sentences of a fine of Â£5 or three months' imprisonment.
verdict: Conviction altered to match charge; sentence upheld
rationaleHighlights: Conviction for riot was invalid as it was not the charge brought
Appellate court has power to correct form of judgment under Cap 10
Substance of guilt upheld despite mislabeling
Appeals of unconvicted accused dismissed for lack of standing
confidenceNotes: High confidence; details are clearly stated in the judgment, including charges, legal provisions, and appellate reasoning.
